Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: From the learner's perspective: Unpacking the why and how of model-based learning about biological systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purposes of this study are to promote and understand how undergraduate students learn foundational biology ideas in introductory biology courses. It will implement and study an innovative approach, which has students learn biological explanations by modeling phenomena as biologists do. The approach directs students to think about structures, behaviors and functions in nature, and to write these out and discuss them. This study will explore in detail student reasoning while they do this and how they learn. The project has potential not only to advance the field's ability to measure student competencies that are valued in recent science education standards documents (e.g., NGSS), but also to advance the field's understanding of how student "modeling ability" develops in a particular discipline. In this way, it can provide an important foundation for other research on the learning of modeling practices in science. Moreover, because the innovations take place in an introduction to biology course and introduction to biology is required for a large number of college majors, the project can be transformative for a large number of students across the country.

This study will be conducted in a pre-designed undergraduate biology course across four universities, two public and two private, serving diverse populations. The aims are: (1) propose systems thinking skills needed by biology students, by (a) getting feedback from academics, and reviewing; (2) to examine more closely student thinking during their activities by (a) recording group discussions, (b) conducting clinical interviews with a subset of students, and (c) collecting student drawings in response to different prompts than they have used previously that help the instructors better understand what students are thinking; (3) conduct open-ended comparisons between other assessments and their assessments of student models; (4) compare outcomes when students are provided different visual representations as feedback (split-plot design); and (5) make comparisons between different demographic groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

We incorporated conceptual modeling as a core component of instruction and assessment in introductory biology to explore how and in what contexts models served to promote students’ learning about biological systems. Modeling is a foundational practice in biology and by extension, biology education, and supports learners in the construction of a coherent understanding of complex living systems. Working collaboratively across four institutions, we developed a robust portfolio of evidence to explain the role of conceptual modeling in promoting learning about biological systems in undergraduate biology.


Outcome 1. Developing a framework of systems thinking skills. Systems and systems thinking (ST) are cross-cutting concepts in science. Somewhat counterintuitively, the universality of systems and ST undermines our ability to define and describe a clear set of ST skills. Using a document analysis approach, our team reviewed the cross-disciplinary literature on systems thinking to (a) identify the research communities that contributed significantly to the general understanding of ST, (b) summarize the specific contributions of these communities to the definition and application of ST, and (c) inform the development of a tentative ST framework for undergraduate biology education. A key outcome of this analysis was that science education was an isolated and insulated community, tending to cite intra-community more than inter-community.


Outcome 2. Research findings about model-based learning. We created a set of isomorphic prompts (models, essays) to explore the impact of item format on the knowledge introductory biology students tap when reasoning about evolution by natural selection. Our research found that student-generated models show greater organization and synthesis of ideas; on essays, students included more content knowledge, but lacked clear organization of their ideas. We also explored whether students’ reasoning was consistent across model types. Using two staples of phylogenetic trees, we found that student reasoning was impacted by phylogenetic tree style.


In collaboration with Wyse (Co-PI), we explored introductory biology students’ thinking about the dynamic nature of systems. Students constructed a model of carbon movement in a local ecosystem and then used their model to reason about how changes in one carbon pool impacted carbon movement. Our findings suggest that over time and in response to instruction, student models develop in complexity and accuracy; however, students’ reasoning about the dynamics of the system remains limited and focused on changes in pool sizes rather than flux rates.


Outcome 3. Research findings about model-based teaching practices. Partnering with Bray Speth (Co-PI), we developed, piloted, and refined a rapid response rubric (3R) focused on student understanding of key principles of evolution by natural selection. We deployed the 3R in several sections of introductory biology, developing instruction related to both student-constructed models and short essays. The 3R was used in two ways: (1) in class as a component of several peer-review activities and (2) as instructor-provided feedback on student’s individually constructed models and essays, including a homework assignment, unit exam, and in class review assignment. We collected models and essays from students both pre- and post-instruction. Students and instructors found the rubric efficient and helpful in promoting their learning of key principles of natural selection. In addition, we developed a short video to promote instructor and student use of modeling in undergraduate classrooms.


Broader Impacts

From the pandemic to climate change, our society is facing myriad complex challenges. The need for skills to reason about complex, dynamic systems is essential to finding and implementing solutions. Our research expands our knowledge-base of how students reason about systems and the role of models in developing systems thinking skills. At NDSU, this research has impacted students and faculty across the biology curriculum. Over 1000 students have learned in introductory biology courses that incorporated model-based learning pedagogy. Further, has diffused vertically to upper division courses including General Ecology, Hormones and Behavior, Plant Physiology, and Ecological Physiology. We have disseminated instructional strategies and materials at local and national conferences, and through an Evidence-Based Teaching Guide on Modeling as a special feature in CBE-Life Sciences Education.


Professional development. This project directly supported the development of four graduate research assistants, five undergraduate research assistants, and two non-student research assistants. In addition, this project has interacted with the REU program, Growing Up STEM (NSF DUE-1560142) to support one summer research participant.
